item.title: If It's Worth Doing Well, It's Worth Doing Poorly
item.description: I once heard a saying that if “something is worth doing well, then it’s worth doing poorly” in this particular case it was in reference to keeping a diet and was along the lines of “done is better than perfect” or “better something than nothing”. So keeping with the diet example, every time I’ve failed at keeping a diet it’s been something along the lines of quitting because “I already messed up yesterday”, while the times I’ve been able to keep a diet were the times I was allowed to make mistakes, or when I had already factored in something like a cheat day.

item.title: Shoe Dog: A Memoir by the Creator of Nike
item.description: This is a memoir by/for Phil Knight, one of the founders of Nike and covers his life from the time of finishing college until Nike went public. It’s rare that I can read a book that I can’t put down and ends up cutting into my sleep because I just want to read one more chapter or know “what’s going to happen next” or wonder “how are they going to pull that off”.

item.title: Build in the open
item.description: Why have my notes be public? This is in large part due to two different ideas. The first is that building in the open aka building with the garage door open allows for better feedback loops with other people. People can tell me where/how I’m wrong, maybe my wisdom/failing can help someone else, those who are curious about me can know what I’m thinking and instead of having something private I can instead be building a kind of resource that could create a kind of creation momentum.

item.title: Heroes Being Human
item.description: Yesterday I was fortunate to find PBS - The Making of Ponyo and it was insightful into the of someone I’ve alway looked up to profesionally, Hayao Miyazaki. I think the best parts weren’t the parts they focused on, they were mostly trying to capture his process (which if I’m being honest is very similar to video game concept art processes), but what was even better was watching him procrastinate, and search for inspiration and dealing with his own internal doubts.

item.title: Ogre Battle - Game Mechanics Study
item.description: I want to explore the mechanics of Ogre Battle because I want to clone a lot of it’s features into a game I’m working on. Not a direct clone but heavily inspired by almost like using this game as a template or a foundation. Ogre Battle Released on the SNES in 1993 and later for the PSX in 1997, this game named after not one but two Queen songs is one of my favorite games.

item.title: About
item.description: I’m what happens when you take an artist, turn them into a designer and then later a developer. My lifelong mission (other than finding the perfect lemonaide) is to use technology to make better and cheaper art. This explains my interests in Neural Networks (especially being used to create things), it’s why I love things like procedural generation, and It’s why I get excited about game engines being used in ways other than for making games.

item.title: What Am I Doing Now?
item.description: June 2020 Learning: I’m learning how to make a game using Unreal Engine 4. I’m making something that’s a spiritual successor to Ogre Battle: March of the Black Queen for SNES, but with RTS elements and a customizable AI Gambit System (like Final Fantasy 12 or Dragon Age). I’ve also started working through Harvard CS50 again as I never finished it and would like to. Reading: I’m reading “Procedural Storytelling in Game Design” by Tanya X.
